messages.message: Hey turkey. Our paths probably won’t cross for a while l, but may I suggest you attack Russia? I’ve seen way to many games where Russia is ignored and all of the sudden they have half the board. Anyways, good lucks and have fun!
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Hey turkey. Our paths probably won’t cross for a while l, but may I suggest you attack Russia? I’ve seen way to many games where Russia is ignored and all of the sudden they have half the board. Anyways, good lucks and have fun!'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's suggestion to attack Russia aligns with a common strategic consideration in the game and indicates a potential willingness to collaborate against a shared threat.

messages.message: Thanks! I'll definitely see what I can do, a big Russia is just as bad for me as everyone else

messages.message: I was talking with Russia, negotiating over Norway and such. They told me they were planning on attacking you, as they thought I was there ally. The truth is, I really don't want to see russia run off with this game, so I decided to let you know.
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'I was talking with Russia, negotiating over Norway and such. They told me they were planning on attacking you, as they thought I was there ally. The truth is, I really don't want to see russia run off with this game, so I decided to let you know.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's detailed explanation of the situation involving Russia's intentions towards Turkey, with a genuine concern about balancing the game dynamics, demonstrates a transparent and collaborative approach that indicates a willingness to work together against a common threat.

messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Thanks for the heads up'.
